In July, a Gallup Organization poll asking how people felt about a broadening of our traditional notions of marriage showed only 36 percent approval for the idea.
 
 This is exactly the same percentage of respondents who, in February, told Gallup that we shouldn't expand the legal definition of marriage.

 In February 1965, more than two years before the U.S. Supreme Court struck down remaining state laws prohibiting whites from marrying blacks, Gallup found that 48 percent of respondents in a national poll still approved of such prohibitions.
 
 Elsewhere in the blinkered past, 51 percent of Americans in a February 1959 Gallup poll said they favored amending the Constitution so that each state could "decide for itself what it wants to do about integration of white and [black] students in the schools."
 
 In June 1963, fully 42 percent of Americans told Gallup they opposed laws to give blacks "the right to be served in public places such as hotels, restaurants [and] theaters."
 
 We've come a long way.
 
 In 1958, Gallup found 94 percent of Americans disapproved of interracial marriage. A similar poll taken earlier this year found only 19 percent disapproved.
 
 From 1973 to 1996, National Opinion Research Center data show the percentage of Americans who said they felt homeowners should be allowed to refuse to sell to people based on race dropped from 63 to 29.
 
 Those numbers are still too high, but they've dwindled into the disreputable margins, as discriminatory thoughts and practices tend to do.
 
 And though the line on the graph of progress in civil rights hasn't been exactly smooth, the trend in the last half-century illustrates Martin Luther King's saying, "The arc of history is long, but it bends toward justice."
 
 Historical opinion polls offer a reality check to anyone who thinks the gay-rights movement suffered a permanent setback when 11 out of 11 states approved referendums calling for a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage.
 
 Though the African-American struggle for acceptance and equality has been different in many ways from the gay struggle, the long-term polling trends tell a similar story.
 
 A review of public opinion on gay rights published earlier this year by the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative think tank, noted a "substantial liberalization in attitudes toward homosexuality" since the mid-1970s.
 
 The 56-page report (see my Tribune Web log) shows how agreement with the following statements has changed over time: 
 
 Gay sex is always wrong: 1973, 70 percent; 2002, 53 percent. 
 
 Homosexuality is an acceptable lifestyle: 1982, 34 percent; 2003, 46 percent. 
 
 I'm not uncomfortable around gays: 1983, 40 percent; 2000, 60 percent. 
 
 Gays should be allowed to teach in elementary schools: 1977, 27 percent; 2004, 61 percent. 
 
 I could support a gay person for president: 1978, 26 percent; 1999, 59 percent. 
 
 People are born homosexual: 1977, 12 percent; 2003, 38 percent. 
 
 I have a friend or close acquaintance who is gay: 1985, 22 percent; 2000, 56 percent. 
 
 Almost the only area in which you don't see this pattern of liberalization is in attitudes about gay marriage. Approval was only at 12 percent in 1988 when the first known poll was taken, according to the AEI report, but that needle has been stuck for more than a decade at roughly a third of the population, depending on exactly how the pollsters word their questions.

 This particular arc in history is a rainbow.
